CONSENSUS ASSESSMENTS INITIATIVE QUESTIO:
Are audit and assurance policies, procedures, and standards established, documented,
approved, communicated, applied, evaluated, and maintained?
__2:
Instructure's security program is managed by our Chief Information Security and Privacy Officer (CISPO), who has ultimate responsibility for managing the program, signing policy, and ensuring its ongoing improvement. Underneath the CISPO, Instructure's security team are talented, skilled, and experienced information security professionals. They are responsible for establishing strong security practices throughout Instructure via governance, risk management, policy, education, security engineering, security compliance, security operations, and application security.

Instructures policies and standards are made available to employees where required, and are referenced in annual security and awareness training. 

Instructure's information security policies and standards are based on information security best practices as set forth by the International Organization for Standardization's (ISO) 27000 suite of standards, NIST's 800-53 suite of controls, and the AICPA's Trust Service Principles and Criteria. Instructure holds SOC 2 Type II reports, TX-RAMP Certifications, ISO 27001 certification, and CyberEssentials+ certification.

CONSENSUS ASSESSMENTS INITIATIVE QUESTIO:
Does the testing strategy outline criteria to accept new information systems,
upgrades, and new versions while ensuring application security, compliance adherence,
and organizational speed of delivery goals?
__2:
All functional code changes are required to be thoroughly reviewed and tested by one or more engineers other than the author. All code changes are also required to have appropriate automated tests written before the change is accepted, both for new features and bug fixes. 
 
Once new code has passed peer review, the code is incorporated into the code base and submitted to testing and quality assurance. The new code is deployed to a continuous integration server where it is immediately tested. Instructure’s testing team runs the following types of tests: 
 
 ● Unit tests (testing code with code)
 ● Integration tests (testing code with integrations with other code)
 ● Browser tests (testing how code works in the browser) on all the different environments and across different databases.

CONSENSUS ASSESSMENTS INITIATIVE QUESTIO:
Is business-critical equipment supplemented with redundant equipment independently
located at a reasonable minimum distance in accordance with applicable industry
standards?
__2: Instructure uses multiple AWS regions and Availability Zones (AZ) for business continuity and recovery. Each region has multiple, geographically-separate backup locations. For example, should a disaster occur within a customer's region, they can failover to another Availability Zone within their geographical region since data is near-time replicated across multiple Availability Zones. Static data is also replicated across multiple geographic locations in an AWS region (through AWS S3) and application servers use elastic load balancing (AWS ELB) to ensure that server resources are available and adjust automatically according to current load. In the most extreme scenarios, for example, the complete loss of a customer's hosting region, a disaster recovery process would occur and a customer would be moved to another AWS region for business continuity purposes until such time that their geographical region was made available again.
__7:
Supplement business-critical equipment with redundant equipment independently
located at a reasonable minimum distance in accordance with applicable industry
standards.

CONSENSUS ASSESSMENTS INITIATIVE QUESTIO:
Are risks associated with changing organizational assets (including applications,
systems, infrastructure, configuration, etc.) managed, regardless of whether asset
management occurs internally or externally (i.e., outsourced)?
__2:
Instructure is conscientious about change management for our customers, and thus we take specific measures to eliminate difficulty through our approach.
 
 A) Instructure applies an Agile methodology with an integrated Quality Assurance (QA) process to the design, development, and maintenance of its products and services. Every day during the three-week cycle, Instructure's engineering team holds a “stand-up” meeting to review progress and discuss any concerns. Engineers write automated unit and integration tests to cover all new code that is written.
 B) All code changes are run through the full QA test suite and appropriately authorized before they can be accepted into the main product. Code changes are closely reviewed and must be peer-approved by other engineering team members before inclusion in the upgrade/update package.
 C) After the three-week development cycle, all changes are deployed to an internal staging server for additional QA testing. Instructure's QA team reviews all associated tickets, uses black-box testing of affected components, and also test standard application workflows. Notes are made on the internal tickets for these changes as needed. Any bugs that are found must be fixed during this QA period, otherwise the change is pulled for further development.
 D) Prior to release to the production environment, all upgrade/update packages are released to a non-production environment (by authorized staff) where the users of our client institutions can test drive and comment on new and changed features and functionality. Preliminary release notes are generated for the upcoming release and made available to all users at https://releases.instructure.com and updated during the QA process. Once the upgrade/update packages are ready for production, only authorized staff can deploy the changes.
 
 For more detail, Instructure's change management policies are outlined in our SOC 2 Type II reports, available for your review upon execution of a Non-Disclosure Agreement.
__7:
Manage the risks associated with applying changes to organization
assets, including application, systems, infrastructure, configuration, etc.,
regardless of whether the assets are managed internally or externally (i.e.,
outsourced).

__2:
Instructure maintains data protection and handling procedures for different data types/classifications based on our Data Classification, Handling, and Encryption Policy. For cryptographic Key Management, we ensure:
 
 a. Cryptographic keys are generated and stored in a secure manner that prevents loss, theft, or compromise.
 b. Cryptographic keys are never stored in clear text in code repositories.
 c. Only authorized personnel have access to plaintext cryptographic keys.
 d. User access to cryptographic keys is documented and approved.
 e. User access to cryptographic keys is reviewed quarterly for appropriateness.
 f. Production encryption keys are not used outside of production environments.
 g. Cryptographic keys are replaced if the confidentiality or integrity is suspected of being compromised.
 h. Cryptographic keys are rotated when personnel having plaintext access are terminated.
 i. Cryptographic keys are rotated at least once annually.
 j. All key management activities should be logged and audited to identify misuse.

__2:
Instructure employees utilize unique IDs to authenticate to systems, and policy prohibits users from directly authenticating using service accounts. Access to internal company systems, including source code repository tools, code review tools, and internal ticketing systems, requires network authentication with a valid user ID and password. Internal network password parameters include:
 
 ● prevent the reuse of at least the last 15 passwords
 ● restrict the use of 3 or more repeating characters
 ● restrict the use of a password that contains a user's display name or username
 ● check a user's proposed password against a list of known weak passwords and dictionary words
 ● limit authentication attempts to 5 times prior to account lockout for 60 minutes.

The policy applies to all of Instructure, including, but not limited to, Instructure personnel, systems, processes, buildings, and other assets.Vulnerability Management is based on the ongoing, repeating process of identifying vulnerabilities, assessing vulnerabilities, and mitigating vulnerabilities base on overall risk rating. Instructure's security team conducts regular vulnerability scans of production environments using both off-the-shelf and custom internally-built tools. We also contract a third-party to perform ongoing external penetration testing, the results of which we publish publicly online annually.

 On all Instructure devices, we utilize enhanced endpoint detection and response (EDR) software with alert triggering on all devices, above and beyond standard antivirus.

__2: Instructure schedules remediation of vulnerabilities based on Critical, High, Medium, or Low risks. For example, if a Critical (emergency) security risk is detected that has a near-and-present-danger, fixing the vulnerability is given the highest priority by Instructure’s security and engineering teams and security patches as such will be applied within twenty-four (24) hours by best commercial efforts. In most cases, vulnerabilities can be fixed using a hot patch without incurring any downtime to production environments.

CONSENSUS ASSESSMENTS INITIATIVE QUESTIO:
Is vulnerability remediation prioritized using a risk-based model from an
industry-recognized framework?
__2:
At Instructure, we assess security risks based on two factors: Impact and Likelihood. 
 ● Impact: Impact is the perceived, calculated, or actual impact that might occur if the identified vulnerability is exploited.
 ● Likelihood: Likelihood is the probability of the vulnerability being exploited.
 Each of these factors are then rated Critical, High, Medium, or Low. For example, if a Critical security risk is detected that has a near-and-present-danger, fixing the vulnerability is given the highest priority by Instructure’s security and engineering teams and security patches as such will be applied within twenty-four (24) hours by best commercial efforts. In most cases, vulnerabilities can be fixed using a hot patch without incurring any downtime to production environments. Other patches to the operating system, application software, and code libraries are rated accordingly. The Overall Risk is calculated by taking the lesser of the two values. (e.g., if Likelihood = Low, and the Impact = High, the Overall Risk = Low). The Overall Risk is then used to prioritize the mitigation of vulnerabilities. We will not hesitate to raise a security risk-level where necessary for the safety and protection of our customers. As a SaaS platform, we have an industry-standard SLA for remediation of vulnerabilities. Our work remediating any vulnerabilities found is always at no additional cost to our customers.
__7:
Use a risk-based model for effective prioritization of vulnerability
remediation using an industry recognized framework.

CONSENSUS ASSESSMENTS INITIATIVE QUESTIO:

__2: Any vulnerabilities detected during penetration tests (internal or external) are filed to our issue-tracking system, Jira. Once entered, they are assigned internal vulnerability ranking according to the OWASP risk rating framework based on likelihood and impact, outlined in TVM-08.1. These issues are tracked through to resolution in accordance with company policy and industry best practice recommendations. Our processes are evaluated against both SOC 2 and ISO 27001 standards.
__7:
Define and implement a process for tracking and reporting vulnerability
identification and remediation activities that includes stakeholder notification.
